bibl.title: Despatch from Ezekiel E. Smith to William F. Wharton, February 17, 1890
Despatches from United States Consuls in Monrovia, 1852-1906

correspAction.roleName: U.S. Minister Resident and Consul General

div1.p: Consulate General of the United States, Monrovia, Liberia, Feby 17th, 1890
Mer. Ezekiel E. Smith To the Department of State.
Consulate General of the United States, Monrovia, Liberia, February 17th 1890.
Honorable William F. Wharton, Assistant Secretary of State, Washington, D. C.

Sir: I have the honor respectfully to acknowledge the receipt of your No. 12 Dispatch of January the 8th, informing me that the despatch paper requested in my No. 42. of November 11th, 1889, had been ordered to be sent.

The supplies, consisting of flag, record book etc, previously forwarded, came per s.s. "Banin" which reached here on yesterday. I received Bill of lading for the same, and sent aboard the steamer for the ease, but the officers on the steamer failed to find it though they turned about and moved hundreds of other cases in search for it. I hope to receive it, however, on the homeward voyage of the steamer.
I am, sir, your obedient servant,
Ezekiel E. Smith. U.S. Consul General
